field_edited_text.value:
Launching the S.S. Patrick Henry, Fairfield yards, Sept. 1941

The Peale Museum, Baltimore





industries and had little of the highly prof-
itable general cargo business. Moreover,
there was vigorous competition from Norfolk
and other East Coast ports and Baltimore’s
older piers and warehouses had become
obsolescent. The railroads owned most of
the major port facilities and were them-
selves in serious financial difficulty and in

no position to make expensive

improvements.

Those concerned with the well being
of the City and the state recognized that
immediate concerted action was needed if
the port was to regain its competitive posi-
tion and the harbor recapture its historical
role as the focal point for urban activities.
The response was public intervention in
two decisive arenas.

In 1956 the state legislature created
the Maryland Port Authority, later reorgan-
ized as the Maryland Port Administration,
to revitalize the port. Since its inception
the Maryland Port Administration has
invested over $300 million in the construc-
tion and improvement of marine terminals,

enabling the port to capture new trade
and to regain its position as a leading,
diversified center of commerce.

In the late 1950’s the City and the
downtown business community adopted
the Charles Center urban renewal plan, an
effort to inject new life into a downtown
then in a serious state of decline. The Cha-
rles Center project was a stepping stone to
the much larger Inner Harbor renewal
plan which in less than twenty years has
transformed a dirty, derelict waterfront
into the most desirable location for com-
mercial, office, and tourist activity in the
region.





10
